document.masterDocTitle: A synopsis of the Neotropical genus Nephepeltia (Odonata: Libellulidae), including description of a new species, synonymies, and a key to males

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A synopsis of the Neotropical genus Nephepeltia (Odonata: Libellulidae), including description of a new species, synonymies, and a key to males

, holotype male, lateral view. (a) Thorax; (b) S1–3; (c) S4–5; (d) S6–10.

Diagnosis. Both sexes of
Nephepeltia leonardina
can be distinguished from congeners by radial planate consisting of four or five cells (
Fig. 3
f; three in other species,
Figs. 3
a–e; g) and base of Fw discoidal field usually with two rows of cells ( 5 % of examined specimens with one cell in one or both wings; always one row in other species). Males are also unique by venter of thorax smoothly convex (
Fig. 6
d; with a tubercle or spine in other species,
Figs. 6
a–c; 7 ; 8 ), spurs of inner row of male hind tibiae closely set and peg-like at medial 0.33 (
Fig. 2
f; either of about uniform length and placement or short and more closely set at basal 0.50–0.75 , and gradually increasing in length apically,
Figs. 2
a–e; g), and outer branch of male hamule forming an anteriorly directed blunt hook (
Figs. 9
e; 10g ; rounded in other species,
Figs. 9
a–d, f; 10 a–f, h). Male vesica spermalis is similar to that of
N. phryne
by its latero-ectal distal lobes in the shape of curved spines and the absence of a medio-ectal distal process (
Figs. 11
e–f; latero-ectal lobes triangular, rectangular or oval and medio-ectal distal process vestigial to well developed in other species;
Figs. 11
a–d).

Distribution.
Nephepeltia leonardina
extends from Panama south to NW Argentina and Paraguay (
Fig. 16
), where adults frequent ponds along rivers, marshes, and sloughs.
